channel.title: BBC Sport

item.title: Was Slovakia win NI's best performance under O'Neill?
item.description: Former Northern Ireland strikers David Healy and Gerry Armstrong believe Friday's World Cup qualifying win over Slovakia was NI's best performance under Michael O'Neill.

item.title: The stats that say Haaland will run away with Golden Boot
item.description: BBC Sport looks at why it looks inevitable that Erling Haaland will win the Premier League Golden Boot this season.

item.title: What Rangers could expect from Gerrard: The sequel
item.description: As Rangers consider a return for Steven Gerrard, BBC Scotland examines his past Ibrox achievements and his record since leaving.

item.title: How McTominay became a 'brother of Naples'
item.description: Scotland midfielder Scott McTominay reflects on his brilliant first season at Napoli, where he wants to keep giving his "absolute best".

item.title: Was Tuchel right to criticise England fans?
item.description: BBC Sport looks into Thomas Tuchel's criticism of England fans during their comfortable friendly win over Wales.

item.title: Captain, player, manager, Mister, number one - Davids at Barnet
item.description: BBC Sport remembers Edgar Davids' 15 months as Barnet player-manager in League Two and the Conference.

item.title: Stop expecting perfection from us - top referee
item.description: In an interview with the BBC, referee Anthony Taylor criticises the "expectation of perfection" culture officials are subject to.

item.title: Does Scotland performance matter if win is outcome?
item.description: Captain Andy Robertson was in no mood to sour the Scotland feeling after their win over Greece, but was the performance a concern?

item.title: O'Neill hails NI 'quality' after key win but rues Bradley ban
item.description: Northern Ireland boss Michael O'Neill says his side were "excellent" in their 2-0 win over Slovakia in World Cup qualifying.

item.title: Northern Ireland outclass Slovakia in Belfast
item.description: Watch the best of the action as Northern Ireland beat Slovakia 2-0 in their World Cup qualifier at Windsor Park in Belfast.

item.title: 'My family no longer attend matches because of abuse by fans'
item.description: Premier League referee Anthony Taylor says his family "no longer attend matches" after the abuse they faced from Roma fans after the 2023 Europa League final.

item.title: Scotland strike late to beat Greece in frantic finish
item.description: Watch the best of the action as Scotland score twice late on to beat Greece and boost their hopes of qualifying for next summer's World Cup finals.

item.title: Putellas, Dumornay and Brugts - UWCL Week One best goals
item.description: The Women's Champions League 2025/26 league phase opens with stunning strikes from Alexia Putellas, Melchie Dumornay, Esmee Brugts and more.

item.title: I feel strong, fit and confident - Rice positive after win
item.description: England and Arsenal midfielder Declan Rice talks to BBC Sport about his preferred playing position following England's 3-0 win over Wales.

item.title: Spurs want Brentford's Schade - Saturday's gossip
item.description: Brentford forward Kevin Schade a target for Spurs, Real Madrid prefer Crystal Palace centre-back Marc Guehi to Liverpool defender Ibrahima Konate while the Merseyside club eye Bayern Munich defender Dayot Upamecano, plus more.

item.title: WSL latest: Slegers looks to Federer to help end Arsenal slump
item.description: Arsenal manager Renee Slegers has shown her players videos of Roger Federer as part of her attempts to halt their poor form.

item.title: Wales' fate in own hands after rivals draw
item.description: Belgium are held to a goalless draw by North Macedonia, who remain top of European World Cup qualifying Group J, with Wales third.

item.title: Passmoor lands three-year deal as Leicester City boss
item.description: Leicester City announce former interim manager Rick Passmoor as their head coach on a permanent basis on a three-year deal.

item.title: 'We tried' - Rooney defends his England team
item.description: England legend Wayne Rooney does not think current squads have a better attitude than his so-called golden generation.

item.title: Harsh lessons and 'hurt egos' for Bellamy's Wales
item.description: Craig Bellamy and Wales learn harsh lessons in their 3-0 defeat at England, in preparation for their big World Cup qualifier against Belgium.

item.title: What do people of Salford think about British flags and Gary Neville?
item.description: BBC Sport speaks to Salford residents about their views on Gary Neville's flag comments and modern British patriotism.

item.title: Monaco sack Hutter after poor run of results
item.description: Monaco sack Adi Hutter as coach after two seasons in charge following a poor run of results.

item.title: From Wolves struggles to Ballon d'Or contention
item.description: BBC Sport NI charts Vitinha's rise from an unsuccessful loan spell at Wolves to finishing third in the Ballon d'Or after helping PSG to win the Champions League.

item.title: Geyoro 'needs two or three months' to adapt to WSL
item.description: It could take £1m London City Lionesses signing Grace Geyoro until December before she is up to speed in the Women's Super League, says manager Jocelyn Precheur.

item.title: 'Chronic Scotland prevail in Hampden head-wrecker'
item.description: Scotland somehow emerge from a bizarre World Cup qualifier with another victory on a remarkable night at Hampden, writes Tom English.

item.title: 'No easy way back for Bellingham as Rogers vindicates Tuchel's strategy'
item.description: There is no easy way back for Jude Bellingham as Morgan Rogers shows he is the symbol of Thomas Tuchel's new England identity, says Phil McNulty.

item.title: Who would you pick for Wales' qualifier v Belgium?
item.description: Wales face a huge game in their bid to reach the 2026 World Cup on Monday - who would you pick in your team to face Belgium?

item.title: 'No energy' - Tuchel unhappy at 'silent' Wembley
item.description: England boss Thomas Tuchel sees his side score three times in 20 minutes in their 3-0 friendly win over Wales, but is left frustrated by the Wembley atmosphere.

item.title: How Scotland can seal World Cup play-off by Sunday
item.description: How close are Scotland to a first World Cup since 1998 after they beat Greece 3-1 in qualifying?

item.title: Saudi sport supremo's Man Utd 'takeover' post prompts questions
item.description: Manchester United sources reject claims made by Saudi sports supremo Turki Alalshikh that the club is in advanced negotiations over a sale to a new investor.

item.title: How England U21 boss Carsley got his start in Derby
item.description: England Under-21 manager Lee Carsley reflects on how his career started on a doorstep in Derby before his return to the city.

item.title: Algeria seal place at 2026 World Cup - who else has qualified?
item.description: BBC Sport's Ask Me Anything team looks at who has qualified for next year's Fifa World Cup.

item.title: Rapper, philanthropist, muse... and Netherlands' record scorer
item.description: Rapper, philanthropist, muse - Memphis Depay is not your conventional footballer, but he is Netherlands' all-time top scorer.

item.title: 'It saved me' - how Everton in the Community is changing lives
item.description: Everton defender James Tarkowski speaks with lifelong fan Sam to discuss how the club are supporting members of the community with mental health challenges.

item.title: 'Results are what qualify you and these Scotland players understand that'
item.description: Scotland head coach Steve Clarke praises his players' resilience and desire in their comeback World Cup qualification win over Greece.

item.title: The day Wales beat England at Wembley
item.description: Wales face England on Thursday hoping to repeat the heroics of their 1977 predecessors.

item.title: 'We've got mountains to do' - Cavallo on homophobia in football
item.description: Josh Cavallo, who plays for Peterborough Sports in Australia and came out as gay in 2021, tells BBC Sport football has "mountains to do" in tackling homophobia in the game.

item.title: Injury woes made Stones think about retirement
item.description: Speaking to BBC Radio 5 Live, England and Manchester City defender John Stones says he considered retiring last season because of injury.

item.title: Sutton says calls for Postecoglou's sacking 'ridiculous'
item.description: Mark Chapman is joined by Chris Sutton and Rory Smith on the Monday Night Club to discuss Ange Postecoglou's results at Nottingham Forest, as Sutton calls fans "entitled" amid sacking calls.

item.title: I can raise my voice about injustice - Bellerin
item.description: Former Arsenal defender Hector Bellerin talks to Elizabeth Conway about his attempts to live a more sustainable life after being named global champion at the BBC Green Sport Awards.

item.title: Lammens' confidence grew on Man Utd debut - Schmeichel
item.description: Former Manchester United goalkeeper Peter Schmeichel praises 23-year-old Senne Lammens' performance for the Red Devils in their 2-0 victory over Sunderland.

item.title: Football or rugby? The new kick-off trend in the Premier League
item.description: Alex Scott, Steph Houghton and Chris Sutton discuss the increase in kick-offs that have been kicked straight out of play, or sent long into the final third, and why it's happening.

item.title: Rooney questions work ethic of 'lost' Salah
item.description: Wayne Rooney, Kelly Somers, Kae Kurd and John Gibbons from The Anfield Wrap discuss Liverpool's loss of form, and why their talisman Mohamed Salah looks "lost".

item.title: 'One of our best ever' - why Pickford is England's undisputed number one
item.description: BBC Sport looks in depth at the game of England goalkeeper Jordan Pickford, with the help of former Three Lions shot-stoppers Paul Robinson and Rob Green, and his former Toffees team-mates Wayne Rooney and Theo Walcott.

item.title: 'Being gay in men's football is a very toxic place'
item.description: Australian Josh Cavallo, who moved to England in July to join non-league Peterborough Sports, says football has got "mountains to do" to tackle homophobia.

item.title: 'I deeply hurt people by moving to Saudi Arabia'
item.description: In an interview with BBC Sport, Ashleigh Plumptre says she regrets losing the trust of some LGBT fans in women's football by moving to Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Delays, distrust, dynamic prices - how 'welcoming' will World Cup be?
item.description: BBC Sport explores the issues which could make fans feel less than welcome when the World Cup takes place in the United States next year.

item.title: The younger Mbappe emerging from his brother's shadow
item.description: Being the brother of a football superstar is not easy. But Ethan Mbappe is aiming to emerge from the shadows and make a name for himself.

item.title: Transfers - September to December 2025
item.description: Check out the significant signings and departures in the Premier League, Scottish Premiership, EFL and Women's Super League.

item.title: Manager ins and outs - 2025-26 season
item.description: BBC Sport tracks all the manager ins and outs in the Premier League, Scottish Premiership, Women's Super League, English Football League and National League.

item.title: What is '007' in football?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything Team look at what the tagline of '007' means and where the taunt came from.

item.title: Why did Man Utd's Yoro kick off a match in France?
item.description: BBC Sport's Ask Me Anything team explains why Manchester United's Leny Yoro kicked off a match in France.

item.title: What are penalty retake rules after Roma penalty drama?
item.description: BBC Sport's Ask Me Anything team explains the rules on penalty retakes after Roma took the same penalty three times against Lille in the Europa League

item.title: Why are Kazakhstan part of Uefa?
item.description: BBC Sport's Ask Me Anything team explains why Kazakhstan are part of Uefa.

item.title: Why are some football shin pads so small?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team explore why some football shin pads are so small, and what the laws are around wearing them.

item.title: Why was Calafiori banned from using a towel for throw-ins?
item.description: Arsenal's Riccardo Calafiori was stopped from drying the ball with a towel against Newcastle - but why did that happen?

item.title: Is the Premier League getting younger?
item.description: BBC Sport's Ask Me Anything looks into why increasing number of teenagers and young players are playing in the Premier League this season.

item.title: You are Scotland boss Steve Clarke… What would you do against Belarus?
item.description: Put yourself in the shoes of the Scotland head coach and pick the side and tactics - plus decide what your pre-match team talk would be.

item.title: Morton manager and partner raise £18k in memory of baby daughter
item.description: Remi was only 1lb 4oz when she was born 14 weeks premature in July and died almost three weeks later.

item.title: Ban for teen who took drum from woman at Rangers game
item.description: The 17-year-old boy assaulted St Johnstone employee Beverly Mayer outside Hampden in August 2024.

item.title: Chelsea win WSL player and manager of month awards
item.description: Women's Super League leaders Chelsea win both the player and manager of the month awards for September.

item.title: Hole in her heart & longer left leg - Snoeijs' unusual birth
item.description: Born with a hole in her heart and a leg that grew to be six centimetres longer than the other, Everton's Katja Snoeijs did not experience an ordinary childhood.

item.title: Injured Everton captain Finnigan out until 2026
item.description: Everton club captain Megan Finnigan will not return until 2026 because she requires an operation to repair her ACL injury, confirms manager Brian Sorensen.

item.title: 'Questions will be asked' of Bompastor and Chelsea
item.description: "Questions will be asked" of Sonia Bompastor following Chelsea's underwhelming Women's Champions League draw with Twente, says ex-England forward Lianne Sanderson.

item.title: From farming village to Liverpool icon - the Salah story
item.description: BBC Sport visits Egypt to discover what Mohamed Salah means to the people of the football-mad country, and how a small boy from humble beginnings became a national icon.

item.title: Napoli 'smell blood' & target Premier League's discarded stars
item.description: After Scott McTominay was a hit, Napoli went back to the Premier League for Kevin de Bruyne, could more players follow them to Serie A?

item.title: How does Daniel Levy run Tottenham - and would he ever leave?
item.description: With Tottenham struggling on the pitch and chairman Daniel Levy facing criticism from fans, BBC Sport looks at how the club is run and what the future might hold.

item.title: When River Plate icon Diaz took over fourth-tier Oxford
item.description: Twenty years on from Ramon Diaz's surprising appointment at Oxford United, BBC Sport looks at what happened and how it went.

item.title: East meets west London - the mentor who changed Chelsea
item.description: Vinay Menon knew nothing about football when he went for a meeting at a west London mansion in 2009. A few weeks later he was in the heart of the Chelsea dressing room.

item.title: The air crash and the underdogs - a triumph for a lost generation
item.description: Nineteen years and 10 miles separated Zambia's football team from a lost, golden generation on a fateful night in Libreville.

item.title: The rise and fall of North Korea - the sleeping giant of women's football
item.description: North Korea lags behind most of the rest of the world in several areas. But the hermit state has had an outsized impact on international women's football.
